turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Are you alright?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: Sometimes, when I feel weak, I have these...visions.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: I see things.  My worst fears.  You need to know something, Peter.  I was possessed once.  Like Birdson.  It took Father Lareaux six days to pull me out of it.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: I'm scared I'm slipping back.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We're going to do this.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: You have to say that.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's true.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why did you lie to me about your parents' deaths?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: I was desperate.  I knew you wrote about murders.  I needed a way in.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Close call.  For the first time in a long time, it's really hitting me. Life's tenuous.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: I know it is.  Right after my parents died, I went to the beach...  I was in the water.  Everything was calm.  And then one of those really big waves hit me.  Hard.  Pulled me straight to the bottom.  I struggled and finally ran out of air.  If it hadn't been for my sister who pulled me out, I would've drowned. Legally dead for a couple of minutes is what they told me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No oxygen to the brain.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: Maybe that's my problem.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why didn't you just go along with Townsend.  Get rid of me.  I would've...

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: Until it happens, you're still a human being.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What about after?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: Only your body will remain.  I believe your soul will be at peace.  If we kill you, Satan can't stay.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Plenty of time.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: What are these?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I don't know.  Extra apartment keys. What's it matter?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: Maybe I should check Lareaux's book. It's in the car.  Be right back.  Don't go anywhere.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What can I do?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: You have to be experienced to do this. Just wait outside. Otherwise, you risk killing him.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: I'll be all right.  Peter, at the very end, I think Father was back.  I saw it in his eyes.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: So, what does it mean.  The ark sank and the sun set?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: He's been repeating that since Birdson's exorcism.  I looked in every passage in the Bible and there's nothing about an ark or a sunset that tells us anything.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What did he say to you in French?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: That's his, I don't know, his 'grounding' phrase for me, "together, no matter what."

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Terrific.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: He was trying to tell me something.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: And his message was  "Together, no matter what?"

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: Book five, Deuteronomy, chapter seven, verse five.  "But this shall you deal with them.  You shall break down their altars and burn their graven images with fire."

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: And what's that mean?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: How much time do we have?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: Not a lot.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: Oh, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's me.  Put the gun down.  Maya...

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: Good seeing you again.

turns.speaker: TOWNSEND
turns.text: Whish the circumstances were different.

turns.speaker: TOWNSEND
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: I know who he is.

turns.speaker: TOWNSEND
turns.text: Maya?  What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: I'll explain everything later.  Can you meet me tonight?

turns.speaker: TOWNSEND
turns.text: And what are you thinking we should do now?

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: I've filed a report with Father Frank.

turns.speaker: TOWNSEND
turns.text: A lot of good that'll do.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: We need all the help we can get.

turns.speaker: TOWNSEND
turns.text: I've dealt with these people before, Maya.  They're not going to help us.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: We'll see Father Frank in the morning. There's nothing to be done until then.

turns.speaker: TOWNSEND
turns.text: Alright, Maya.  We'll do it your way.

turns.speaker: TOWNSEND
turns.text: It's useless...look at him.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: You can't back out on me now.  We need to be sure.

turns.speaker: TOWNSEND
turns.text: Sure of what?  Who cares if this guy is devoid of faith or sleeps over a pentacle?  Results are what Lareaux would want.

turns.speaker: TOWNSEND
turns.text: You don't want to face it.

turns.speaker: MAYA
turns.text: Look, John, I'm facing it.

turns.speaker: TOWNSEND
turns.text: I'm not waiting until it's too late.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'd appreciate it if you'd put that back.

turns.speaker: MELVIN
turns.text: You are the younger of two...

turns.speaker: MELVIN
turns.text: But she worships you.  Your mother's dead but your father's alive.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Nothing you couldn't find out from reading the papers.  And you're already wrong on one count.

turns.speaker: MELVIN
turns.text: Viznick will get off and Michael's got a crush on you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You know what?  You can go.

turns.speaker: MELVIN
turns.text: Suit yourself.  But does this mean anything to you?

turns.speaker: MELVIN
turns.text: You do know, don't you.  That these are also numbers.  Greek numbers, 600, 60 and 6 - or 666.  The sign of the Devil.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Get out of here.

turns.speaker: MELVIN
turns.text: Goodbye.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Mr. Kelson, here's the stuff you wanted on pathological narcissism.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What about that psychic, what's his name, Szabo?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: He can see you Thursday.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I think it's gonna be a waste of time.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: The police used him as a witness in this case.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'll be at Bedford tonight, if you need me.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Nice suit.

turns.speaker: MRS. QUINTANA
turns.text: I plan to.  You want a tip?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Lemme guess.  The lottery.

turns.speaker: MRS. QUINTANA
turns.text: Sometimes I can just feel the numbers.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You know what they say.  You have the same chance of winning whether you play or not.

turns.speaker: MRS. QUINTANA
turns.text: You watch.  One day, I'll hit the jackpot, get the big house, car, clothes.  I'll have more money than God.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MRS. QUINTANA
turns.text: It's Detective Smythe.

turns.speaker: MRS. QUINTANA
turns.text: Good of you to stop by.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We millionaires yet?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: As a part of today's story on the trial of mass murderer George Viznick, we welcome Peter Kelson, author of the current best-seller, VICIOUS INTENT. Thank you for joining us, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thanks for having me, Sally.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Peter, you're now writing a book about the Viznick case.  You seem to be making a career of studying sensational murderers.  I have to ask, how does it make you feel when you sit in courtrooms day after day, face to face with alleged killers?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Well, long-term exposure to things like this tends to give you a sort of clinical understanding of the subject. After awhile, you begin to make friends with it, so to speak.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: It's as if you are saying the closer you get to evil, the less evil it becomes.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No, the less mystifying.  Good and evil are only illusions.  There is no such thing as evil with a capital "E."  That suggests some third party bad guy pulling all the strings.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: You're referring to the defense's efforts to prove that George Viznick is tormented by "demonic voices?"

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: There weren't any voices.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Not even from some mental illness, as the prosecution asserts?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: As if there's another cause for little voices?  No, Sally, Viznick's a manipulator, he's clever, he has what I call malignant narcissism.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: What do you mean by that?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Well, we all have a degree of narcissism, Sally, but a malignant narcissist is dangerously self-obsessed.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Are you saying he's legally sane?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Well, George Viznick is in the grayest of gray areas in the sanity spectrum. Viznick is not psychotic. He's simply unable to submit to any higher authority.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Meaning, Viznick's a man who answers to no one.  Not even God.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Right.  If you believe in God.  As a narcissist, Viznick couldn't blame himself for the alleged murders.  He created the voices after the fact.  In order to avoid the simple truth that there is no outside force that guides George Viznick and that George Viznick needs to pay.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: And what about you?  What about Peter Kelson?  Where is your moral compass?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Would you sign it for me?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Hey!  Mr. big shot.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Mike.  Oh, the christening.  I meant to call...

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Yeah, right.  I don't know why I bothered inviting you guys.  I knew you wouldn't show.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: So, Viznick's got a meet with his lawyer in the ayem.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Really?  You know, seeing these guys away from the court, the facade slips. You catch things.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Yeah, yeah.  I've heard it before.  Just be sure you spell my name right.  Nine o'clock?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: So you can see where you're going when you crawl up his asshole.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Seems George isn't making too many friends in lockup.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Yeah, look at that sweet face.  You'd never guess he killed nine people.  I'm gonna get my smokes.  Be right back.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're too old to smoke.  Won't be able to shoot hoops with your grandkid.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He's looking right at me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He could see me.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: I'll quit, maybe you should start.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thanks for handling this.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Sure thing.  Look, I've got enough, between your preliminary statements and all the witness accounts.  You can go home.  Gimme til morning.  Find out who he is. Until then, don't sweat it, huh?  Just your random bad cheese trying to hole you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thanks again for everything.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Hey, don't thank me.  Somebody up there likes you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: How're you doin' today?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's another day.  I think I'm alright.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: You got the right attitude, anyway, look, we gotta talk.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: She came to me with a wild story about demonic possession.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: She's got a juvenile record from New Orleans.  Parents died when she was 13.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Parents died?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Yeah, murder-suicide.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Mother killed the father, then killed herself.  Crime of passion.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: She told me she killed them.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Not what the records show.  Anyway, she was a runaway, arrests for vandalism, petty theft, drugs, the whole bit. Parole records show she graduated from community college, moved into a retreat house, teaches some classes at the seminary school, hasn't been in any trouble since.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: We hauled her in earlier but didn't have anything hard to tie her to Townsend. Far as the priest goes, he won't be bothering you.  Suffered a complete mental breakdown, during - get this - during an exorcism.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Where is she now?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Had to let her go.  I see you thinkin' there, superstar. Don't.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Monica, what did you do?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Oh, all that work.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Ah, Mom.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: I'm lucky I found it.  Someone put your box of dresses under a pile of rags in the garbage.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I hate it.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Fine, you don't like this one, which one would you rather wear?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Pants.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: nothing.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: I don't know why I keep hoping you'll grow out of this tomboy thing.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I won't.  I'm a lesbian.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: That's not funny

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Well, that's what you think, isn't it? Cause I'd rather wear a jersey than an apron...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Watch your mouth.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Taste this.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I can't eat before a game.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Child, take a bite.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: You really should be a caterer or something like you used to say.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Sure.  In between all the other things I have to do.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Nothing.  So good luck.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Tonight, don't worry about yesterday's game, the recruiters, or anything else. I just want you to enjoy being beautiful. Will you do that?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Monica.  What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Didn't know I needed a reason to come home.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Don't be defensive.  I'm just surprised to see you.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Dad around?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: He's still at the bank.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Whenever you lose, you get this attitude. But it's just a game.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Need any help?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: I can manage.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Yeah.  Can't wait to see him  I just saw Quincy.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: How is he?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Engaged.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: To that stewardess?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Yeah, you met her?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: His mother had a cookout a few weeks ago. He could do a lot better if you ask me.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Maybe she is.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: So what do I do?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Find out where they're registered and send them a gift.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Whatever.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: You didn't want my opinion in the first place, so why even ask?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I asked but why does it always have to be so damn prissy.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Don't curse.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: There you go.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: What do you want me to tell you, Monica, to go beat that girl up?  To go have sex with him?  I'm not going to do that. Yes, I believe thinking of other people is important and yes I'd rather bake a pie than shoot a dumb jump shot.  If that makes me too "prissy" for you, too bad.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: So that's why we can't get along? Because I'd rather shoot a "dumb" jump shot?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: You're the one always turning your nose up at me.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: No I don't.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Child, please.  Ever since you were little you thought you were too good for anything I had to say.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I wasn't Lena.  I didn't care about nail polish or lip gloss or sneaking a spray of your perfume.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: What was so wrong with wanting to teach you the things I knew could help you?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Because you're pushing me to be something I'm not.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: So you're angry with me because you're standing here with your hair combed and wearing perfume?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I'm angry because I want a mother, not Martha Stewart.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Oh, yes.  The superstar female athlete whose mother is nothing but a housewife.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: That's not it.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Don't tell me you aren't ashamed of that because I know.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I remember when I was eight years old, you spent like four hours cooking up this fancy meal.  All you'd let me and Lena do was set the table.  And I guess you and Dad got your wires crossed or something because he walks in with a couple of pizzas.  And you didn't say anything. You just threw the whole meal into some tupper-ware and tossed it in the fridge.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: I don't remember that.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I do.  You never stood up for yourself. Ever.  If I was ashamed, it was because of that.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: That's ridiculous.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: What's ridiculous is not being a caterer so your husband can feel like a man knowing his woman's home cooking and ironing his drawers.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: That's all you cared about.  I must have played in a thousand games and I can only remember you being to two.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: You had your coaches and your father for that stuff.  It never mattered one way or the other if I went to your games.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: It mattered, Mom.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: When I said Quincy could do better, I was thinking about you.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: She needs to stop running around like a little boy.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: She's alright.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: How is she alright looking the way she does?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Camille, she'll be fine.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Which one for tomorrow?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: The blue.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: You sure?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Thanks, sweetheart.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: When you're done can you make sure she brushes her teeth?

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Are you okay?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: I just need to lay down.  I've been running around all day.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: ...and if you want a thicker base, you can cut in a potato or just use a little flour.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: But you use potato?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: So that means it's alright for you to act like that?

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: What'd you do?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: So you're still breast-feeding?

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: The doctor said it was okay.  Anyway, I'm still trying to lose some of this baby fat.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: You might want to put a jacket on him, it's getting cold.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: He's fine.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: NONA
turns.text: ...we moved back here when Quincy was about five, after Zeke was traded. Neighborhood was a little more mixed back then...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Until the Black family down the street became the Black family next door.

turns.speaker: NONA
turns.text: Okay?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Well, thanks again.  This was really nice of you.

turns.speaker: NONA
turns.text: It was the least we could do.  And I love to cook.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Oh, me too.  I used to cook for my friends' parties and things back in Atlanta.

turns.speaker: NONA
turns.text: You're a caterer?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Well, no, but once Nathan gets settled and the girls get a little older, it's definitely something I want to do.  Since you love to cook, maybe it's something we can talk about.

turns.speaker: NONA
turns.text: You know, girl, long as I've lived next door, I've never seen the inside of this house.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Really?  Well, come on, then.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I can take it.

turns.speaker: COACH MILLER
turns.text: This time get your feet set.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: COACH MILLER
turns.text: You love to pose so much, let's see it again.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Coach...

turns.speaker: COACH MILLER
turns.text: I want you to stand like that until you're sick of it because I don't ever want to see it again, you hear me?  Dora, take her spot.

turns.speaker: COACH MILLER
turns.text: You could've given up after you threw that ball away.  But you kept your head and you showed real heart.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: COACH MILLER
turns.text: We've got our final games against Oregon and Oregon State and I want to shake things up a bit, so I'm starting you at point again.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I thought Sidra's ankle was okay for next game.

turns.speaker: COACH MILLER
turns.text: You want the job or not?

turns.speaker: COACH MILLER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: It's just...it seems like you're always yelling at me.

turns.speaker: COACH MILLER
turns.text: You think I'd go hoarse for a player with no potential?   When I ignore you, that's when you worry.  Go get dressed.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Can I take your coat?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: You're cold?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: No, I mean I can check it for you.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Oh, sorry.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I'm an English major.  You like English?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Sort of.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Careful.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: That was two words.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I mean, I'm having a good time with you...

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: My mouth is kinda dry.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Then I'll get you some punch.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: That was nice.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Your sister told me hands off, but I can't help myself...

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Wait...

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Shh.  It's okay.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Quincy, word has it you might make the jump the NBA.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: Don't go starting rumors, Jim.  My son's college bound with or without basketball.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You could make a career by telling me where.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: Gotta wait til the press conference.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: But you'd love for him to play at USC, like you did.

turns.speaker: ZEKE
turns.text: I'd love for him to get a good education.  That's it.

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: I'm so sorry.  No one would switch flights with me.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: It's okay.

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: Why are you up?  Get in bed.

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: Kyra, this is Monica.  She, uh...

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: Monica.  You grew up together, right? Quincy's told me about you.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: It means a lot that you came by.

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: Yes, we appreciate that.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: Damn, girl.

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: I don't wanna see that.

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: Get used to it, babe.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: So how long is this trip?

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: Four days.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: Nah.

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: You might be the only one with a job.

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: Baby, don't talk like that.  Your rehab's going well.  You'll be back before you know it.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: Sometimes I wonder if it's worth it. Busting my ass, for what?

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: To do what you love.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: I don't know sometimes.

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: You're just scared.  I know rehab is hard, and you have to worry about whether you'll be as good as you were but you will be.  I believe in you.  You just have to get back on the court.  Like you'd get back on a horse.

turns.speaker: QUINCY
turns.text: A horse?

turns.speaker: KYRA
turns.text: Don't make fun of me when I'm being wonderful and supportive.  You belong on the court.  Just like I belong in the stands, looking cute and cheering you on.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: That too tight?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Mom's going to hate it.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Always on my ass, anyway.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Like you don't give her a hard time.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Just cause I don't kiss her booty like you...

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: You need to.  She's alone in this house all day, taking care of Dad and your ungrateful behind.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: No one's forcing her.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Just try and chill a little bit, alright.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: So what's going on with the Spring Dance? You have a date yet?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Yeah, brothers are lined up at my locker.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: I found you someone.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Found?  I'm not some charity case.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: I know...

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Mom tell you to do this?

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Damn, Lena...  Who is he?

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: This brother from my college.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: He's in college?

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: And he's fine, girl.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: How'd you get him to say yes?

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: I told him you looked like me.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Oh, great.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: You do.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Yeah, right.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: If you were tore up I would not be claiming you.  Trust.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I don't know how to walk in heels.

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Hey.  You just worry about playing your behind off for that recruiter tonight. Let me worry about your date.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: You ever been in love?

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Too many times.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: They ever love you back?

turns.speaker: LENA
turns.text: Yeah, once I cut them off.  Why?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Dad, you have to talk to Coach for me.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: And what am I supposed to say to the man?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: The coach from Tennessee was there and he has me riding the bench.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: You lost your head.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I was just showing emotion.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Monica, I think her point is...maybe it's time to start thinking about other things besides basketball.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: You only have one game left and you haven't been recruited.  Munchkin, I wanted it as bad as you did, but we have to face reality.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: The coach from USC is going to be at the championship.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I know.  But chances are...

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Chances are there's still a chance.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Hey, munchkin.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Dad.  What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I was upstairs for a meeting.  I've been hearing good things about you.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: That tends to happen when you're the boss's daughter.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: So how's the job going?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: You shoot like a girl.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I'll take that as a compliment.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Coach hates me, doesn't she?

turns.speaker: SIDRA
turns.text: She hates all freshmen.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: What's up with that?

turns.speaker: SIDRA
turns.text: Hey, don't take it personal.  And don't think just cause we play the same position we have to compete with each other.  We're teammates, okay?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Thanks, Sidra.

turns.speaker: SIDRA
turns.text: Besides.  I've been starting point the last two years.  Ain't no way some dumb- ass freshman is taking my spot.

turns.speaker: SIDRA
turns.text: That's what you get for trying to show out, freshman.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: I was just playing ball.

turns.speaker: SIDRA
turns.text: You were trying to make me look bad.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Didn't have to try very hard.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: SIDRA
turns.text: Just wanted to say good game.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: But?

turns.speaker: SIDRA
turns.text: No buts.  Took a lot of heart to take that charge.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: SIDRA
turns.text: But that was a dumb-ass pass to Toni. Ten seconds left, you run out the clock.
